abstract.p: Nuclear Whales Saxophone Orchestra, whose instruments include 6-foot-8-inch contrabass sax, will perform with Ocean City Pops in Ocean City, NJ (S)

block.p: They call themselves the Nuclear Whales Saxophone Orchestra, and among their instruments is a saxophone that looks as if it had been exposed to nuclear radiation. ''The world's largest saxophone!'' brags the advance publicity. This is always a dangerous claim to make -- who knows what monstrously enlarged instruments lurk in garages and attics in the neighborhood of, say, Three Mile Island? -- but the 6-foot-8-inch contrabass is certainly the largest saxophone likely to be played on the Jersey Shore this summer.
Orchestra and gigantic sax are coming to the music pier in Ocean City tonight at 8 for a concert with the Ocean City Pops. The group is an all-saxophone sextet that plays a variety of styles.

They call themselves the Nuclear Whales Saxophone Orchestra, and among their instruments is a saxophone that looks as if it had been exposed to nuclear radiation. ''The world's largest saxophone!'' brags the advance publicity. This is always a dangerous claim to make -- who knows what monstrously enlarged instruments lurk in garages and attics in the neighborhood of, say, Three Mile Island? -- but the 6-foot-8-inch contrabass is certainly the largest saxophone likely to be played on the Jersey Shore this summer.
Orchestra and gigantic sax are coming to the music pier in Ocean City tonight at 8 for a concert with the Ocean City Pops. The group is an all-saxophone sextet that plays a variety of styles.

According to the group's Web site, the monster sax will be making a homecoming of sorts. The horn is said to have been found abandoned in a building in Newark in the 1960's; workers rescued it just before tearing the building down. Don Stevens, the orchestra's founder, acquired the instrument from a man in Kentucky in 1989.
